name: cellulose fibre production | cellulose fibre | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23511/documentation

The process describes the production of 1 kg of cellulose fibre from waste paper (post-consumer) used as an insulation material in buildings. Cellulose fibre used for insulation applications has a thermal conductivity of 0.038 W/mK at a density of 30-60kg/m3. The activity starts with the delivery of sorted waste paper and includes the production process. During production, aluminium hydroxide and boric acid are added as flame retardant. The inventory ends, when insulation material can be provided to customer (not including installation (blowing in) or transport to building site). ;;Packaging has also been excluded from the dataset. According to isofloc, 1 Kg of cellulose fibre is linked to the following packaging requirement: 9.87E-04 Kg of plastic foil, 7.26E-03 of PE-bags, and 3.77E-04 Kg of palettes. ;;;Reference: ;;Datenblatt isofloc eco, https://isofloc.ch/assets/Produkte/Zellulosefasern-eco/20150327-isofloc-eco-BUeT-de-mail.pdf;;isofloc AG/sinum AG (2014) ECOPRO Effizienz Profil 2012. BÃ¼tschwil, Switzerland.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - cellulose fibre production, inclusive blowing in, CH, 1995 - 2000 (4ab9848c-4a60-4b37-94b3-affcc711daf6)]

The activity starts with 'waste paper, sorted' and the other process inputs being available to the recycling facility.

The activity ends with 'waste paper, sorted' being recycled into cellulose fibre to be used as insulation material and ready for transportation at the gates of the production facility. Requirements for administration, packaging, and blowing in (including binder) are not covered by this inventory.

exchanges.description:
The amount reflects the sum 3 different inputs provided in the original source. Those 3 inputs are wastepaper from the printshop (0.424 Kg), unsorted waste paper (0.260 Kg) and sorted waste paper (0.236 Kg). 


Source: isofloc AG/sinum AG (2014) ECOPRO Effizienz Profil 2012. BÃ¼tschwil, Switzerland.
